docs.lead_paragraph: A woman and two men were charged today with stabbing a couple to death and stealing their two children. The police said the woman, Adriana Mejia, 22, had persuaded her cousin, Arturo Leon, and an acquaintance, Gabriel Solache, to help her kill the couple, Mariano Soto and his wife, Jacinita. The police said Mrs. Mejia had wanted to steal the Sotos' 2-month-old baby, Guadalupe Marie, whom Mrs. Mejia saw at a health clinic.

headline.main: 3 Accused of Killing Pair to Steal Children

docs.abstract: Chicago police charge Adriana Mejia, Arturo Leon and Gabriel Solache of fatally stabbing Mariano Soto and wife Jacinto and stealing their two children (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: What is good about Robert Shaw's choral performances is often so good that they tend to live in the memory as uniformly wonderful even when they were not. Certainly, Mr. Shaw's performance of Bach's B minor Mass on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall will be remembered most vividly for the work of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chamber Chorus, 50 strong. No surprise, of course. Mr. Shaw's choral wizardry has become familiar to New Yorkers in recent years, primarily through his annual choral workshops at Carnegie Hall, in which he assembles a formidable chorus of motley professionals in the space of a week.
docs.abstract: James R Oestreich reviews Robert Shaw conducting Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chamber Chorus, Orchestra of St Luke's and soloists in Bach's B minor Mass (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jeffrey Brinker, the chief of interventional cardiology at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, began to suspect about a year ago that a widely used heart pacemaker might have a fatal defect. The defect, if it exists, is in a slender wire about the width of a piece of thread. The wire, Dr. Brinker believes, may unexpectedly break and pierce the heart, killing wearers of the pacemaker. But even if the defect exists, and Dr. Brinker has no proof that it does, the problem occurs so infrequently that people wearing the device are more likely to die from having their pacemakers removed than from a defective pacemaker.

headline.main: In Fixing Faulty Medical Devices, the Cure Can Be Worse Than the Disease

docs.abstract: Discovery by doctors at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine that widely used pacemaker may have fatal defect underscores problem arising more and more in medicine that doctors are unsure how to approach; doctors are in quandry over whether in such instances efforts to correct problem are worthwhile since risk from malfunctioning device is infinitesimal, compared with possibility that patients are more likely to die from having pacemaker removed; experts say problem has originated from clash between patients rights movement, culture of litigation and advances in science that allow detection of risks that would otherwise go unnoticed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Quinn Patrick Willman arrived at Northern Westchester Hospital here on Friday the 13th last month, it was his lucky day. Not many babies are born more than eight years after they are conceived. Quinn, a healthy eight pounds, represents the frontier of reproductive medicine -- he is the product of an embryo that was frozen for seven years and seven months. He is believed to be among the oldest ''ice babies'' -- human embryos that were frozen, stored, thawed, implanted in their mother's womb and ultimately delivered nine months -- and however many years -- later as healthy newborns.

headline.main: Baby Is Born to Carmel Couple From Embryo Frozen 7 Years

docs.abstract: Quinn Patrick Willman was born at Northern Westchester Hospital on March 13; Quinn, healthy eight pounds, represents frontier of reproductive medicine; he is product of embryo that was frozen for seven years and seven months, and is believed to be among oldest 'ice babies'; his parents are Karen and Paul Willman of Carmel, NY; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the three weeks since her baby was born, Gina Bruystens, 23, has feverishly, defiantly and exultantly done all the things she could not do when she was pregnant. She has pierced her ears, adding one more hole to the right side and two more holes to the left. She has also dyed her hair, using a bottle of 40 percent peroxide solution that she found at Hot Topic, a punk boutique near her home in Cucamonga, Calif. The goal was white streaks, but instead it all turned a rusty pumpkin orange, an accident she likes enough to keep. Now she is considering a new tattoo. She already has one on her right shoulder, a picture of Bamm-Bamm of ''The Flintstones'' and the name Andrew. It is a tribute to her 5-year-old son, who somehow managed to break a fish tank with his head when he was still a toddler. She imagines a companion image for her left shoulder, a bouncy newborn and the name Michael. He will stay forever a baby on her body because he lives 3,000 miles away in Massachusetts. In early January, Gina gave the boy up for adoption.

headline.main: Now Accepting Applications for My Baby

docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin article on child rearing focuses on increasing number of birth mothers who are giving up children for adoption; interviews Gina Bruystens, who surrendered second child for adoption before birth; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: After 13 years as a commercial litigator, Michael Scully was bored. Sure, he made good money and commanded his share of respect, but his life felt reduced to a predictable round of conference calls and court dates, to the single question of win or lose. More and more he fantasized about pursuing something he'd truly love, something unrelated to law. So in the spring of 1993 he told his wife, Doreen Lorenzo, that he wanted to quit. At the age of 38 he wanted to go back to school for a doctorate in American Studies -- a field that, among other things, offered no guarantee of future employment. And if she agreed, it would be up to her to support their family. That wasn't the sort of thing that a woman who was four months pregnant with her second child wanted to hear.
docs.abstract: Peggy Orenstein article on child rearing focus on increasing number of women have taken over financial control of families from husbands by becoming primary wage earners; she interviews Doreen Lorenzo, whose husband ceded control, quitting job as commercial litigator to return to graduate school for advanced degree; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was pregnant with the girl who made me a mother, the thing I hated most was how my size and shape demonstrated to anyone who laid eyes on me both what was going on in my body and what was going on in my mind. I had a secret, but everyone knew what it was -- I was going to have a baby, which was all I could think about. I wasn't wrong; I subsequently learned that motherhood is the most public of personal conditions. Everyone has an opinion about a mother and her behavior, and lots of those opinions are infuriating. For example, I was of the eat-until-you-are-satisfied school of pregnancy weight gain. My doctor, of course, made remarks about how much I was gaining. After Phoebe was born, 20 years ago, everyone had an opinion about whether to breast-feed, how and how long. I breast-fed for two years. When I nursed at dinner parties or in semipublic places, there were opinions about that, too. Opinions about motherhood in our culture aren't just specific, they are also general. Mothers should stay home, mothers should work, mothers should not hire nannies, mothers should enlist fathers in child care, mothers should stop telling fathers what to do, mothers should be satisfied with being good enough, mothers are never good enough to prevent their own dysfunctions (read ''humanity'') from infecting their children.
docs.abstract: Jane Smiley article on motherhood describes efforts of mothers to find right balance between children and work, family and self; says motherhood is most public of personal conditions, a private experience from which even one's own children are excluded; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When I was pregnant with the girl who made me a mother, the thing I hated most was how my size and shape demonstrated to anyone who laid eyes on me both what was going on in my body and what was going on in my mind. I had a secret, but everyone knew...

docs.lead_paragraph: So May Castleberry's baby was due in two weeks. And though May had attended Lamaze classes with her husband, Michael FitzGerald, and had arranged a leave of absence from her job as a curator at the Whitney Museum, I felt that something was still missing -- a ceremony for the mother to be. There is evidence that 3,000 years ago Egyptians rubbed soothing ointment on pregnant bellies to relieve discomfort and prepare for childbirth. Our culture, it seemed to me, was lacking in prenatal grooming rituals. I was wrong, as it turned out, but that is how I came to take May around to some of the high priests of beauty and fitness in New York to help prepare her for the great event. The first was Susanna Romano, a partner in Salon A.K.S. on Madison Avenue. Susanna said pregnant clients often want to cut their hair very short, but she advises against it, as short hair can be more work than medium length, and she thinks women feel prettier with some locks to toss around. Actually, she would prefer May's chin-length hair even longer, so she just cut some layers to correct the shape, which was rather flat on top and wide at the bottom. Even without blow-drying, May's new do looked soft yet polished.
docs.abstract: Mary Tannen article on prenatal grooming; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There were so many layers of satin to the white christening dress that Rose could hardly find the baby inside. If only this little burden would always stay so light, she thought as she found herself standing at the baptismal bowl, the only white woman in an evangelical church in Brooklyn, about to become the godmother of her nanny's illegitimate child. It was a bit more than she had bargained for six years ago when she hired Jacqueline to care for her children, organize their schedules, buy and cook the meals, keep her house clean and generally make the life of her family possible. Jacqueline -- who is identified by her middle name to protect her privacy, as are all the other characters in this story -- had broken the news of her pregnancy seven months before. She had dragged the vacuum cleaner halfway up the stairs, sat down and begun to cry. Rose, a psychotherapist, had never seen her like that. Normally stalwart, Jacqueline had brought structure, discipline and neatness to the household. As she consoled her nanny, Rose saw her own tightly woven existence unraveling. She could not have been more undone had her husband announced he was leaving. Without Jacqueline, she could not manage.
docs.abstract: Lucinda Franks article on child rearing says child care is inadequate in America, and that children often still pay heavy price, even if mothers have finally started to win acceptance in workplace; notes intimate and uneasy cross-cultural alliances forged between working mothers and their nannies, who sometimes must struggle to meet each other's needs; photos (M)
